results.title: The Man with the movie camera = Chelovek s kinoapparatom
results.brief_description: Writer/Director/Editor, Dziga-Vertov, was made Head of the Cinema Department of the All Russian Central Executive at the age of 22. His film shows all the tricks of which the camera is capable. Vertov shows Russia as it really is; indeed, the final impact of the film arises from a feeling of participation in life itself as we share the unique vision of the camera-eye.

results.title: The Man with the golden gun (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Danjaq, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and Guy Hamilton
results.brief_description: Born in a circus, Francisco Scaramanga (Christopher Lee) is a killer for hire, an ex KGB assassin and the man with the golden gun. When MI5 receives a signature Scaramanga bullet with 007 on it, Bond (Roger Moore) is sent on an undercover mission to locate the man with a million dollar fee. After retrieving a gold bullet from the midriff of an Israeli belly dancer, Bond leaves for the exotic city of Macau where he makes contact with Portuguese weapons expert, Lazar. An assassination attempt reveals that the real target was a missing energy expert who created the Solex Agitator - an energy converter capable of harnessing the sun’s radiation. Ably assisted by Goodnight (Britt Ekland), Bond also finds time to woo Scaramanga’s mistress, Andrea Anders (Maud Adams, who would later appear with Roger Moore in Octopussy). Highlights include James taking on sumo wrestlers and karate experts, a lengthy boat and car chase and impressive use of a fake nipple. The film culminates in a chamber-of-horrors showdown, with red-lit, mirrors and optical illusions and a voiceover by Scaramanga’s short statured sidekick, Nick Nack (Fantasy Islands Herve Villechaiz). Shot across various exotic locations, the film was criticized for 007s uncharacteristic misogyny against his female counterparts.

results.title: The Man with a movie camera: fragments from a cameraman's diary
results.brief_description:
The film’s protagonist is a cameraman travelling through the city involving himself in its daily dawn-to-dusk activities and observing all walks of life through the eye of his camera. Although Vertov’s film has been linked with the so-called ‘city symphonies’, Vertov is not concerned with the abstract formalism of films like Berlin but with a philosophical reflection on the power of the camera over ‘reality’. Vertov rejected the contemporary fiction film in favour of recording unstaged ‘reality’, what he called ‘instants of life’. Yet his concern was also with the nature of cinematographic illusion. He constantly reminds the audience of the camera’s presence and of the film being edited and screened. As such his influence extends across the filmmaking spectrum from cinema verite’s preoccupation with unstaged reality to experimental self-reflexiveness and the preoccupation of filmmakers like Godard with the ideology of representation. Also available on 16mm and VHS.

Credits: Director, script, Dziga Vertov ; photographer, Mikhail Kaufman.

results.title: The Man who thought with his hat (K)
results.brief_description: The amusing, satirical story of Alec Noll, President of Agonia. He was such an important man, but with one strange characteristic…he thought with his hat. Based on a book by Swedish writer, Gunnar Berefelt.

results.title: The Man who stops accidents
results.creator_credit: Technical and Scientific Films and Denis Ward
results.brief_description: Although most managements take precautions to prevent foreseeable accidents, they are still common, a very large percentage being caused by personal carelessness. In this film, the duties of the foreman in accident prevention are stressed. It goes on to show a series of “typical” accidents and “puts the clock back” on them to show how they could have been prevented.

results.title: The Man who skied Antarctica
results.brief_description: Yuichiro Miura, the man who skied down Everest, seeks self-discovery on an Antarctic peak where he encounters storm, crevasse and avalanche. A gripping metaphor of challenge and supreme human perseverance.

results.title: The Man who planted trees (K)
results.creator_credit: Radio Canada, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Frederic Back
results.brief_description: Another award winning title by Frederic Back, creator of the prize winning animated film CRAC, who is showcased in this new half hour film which pays tribute to a man whose toil and dedication brought life to a barren, desolate region high in the French Alps. A triumphant testament to one man’s indomitable spirit. “The Man Who Planted Trees” is a thought provoking tale, a visually stunning tour de force, from a genius in the fine art of animated cinema. Winner of more than 25 awards, including Academy Award, 1988. Narrated by Christopher Plummer and based on a story by Jean Giono.

results.title: The Man who loves frogs: Mike Tyler
results.brief_description: One man’s look at the enormous variety of frog species found in Australia, the differences between them, and the ways each has adapted to its own particular lifestyle/environment.

results.title: The Man who loved machines
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, David Verrall and Sidney Goldsmith
results.brief_description: A humorous, animated science film that introduces students to the nature of energy and energy conservation, as well as to the second law of thermodynamics, entropy. The points are underscored by the observations of an all-seeing dog in need of a doghouse, whose master, though obsessed with machines, is finally convinced that the simplest tool is sometimes the most energy-efficient! Voice and Narration by Terrence Labrosse. Music by Peter Mendieta.
